pros: Lots of benefits. Supportive team mates

pros: Just having a full-time job with decent benefits is a pro. There are some nice people working here.
cons: Salary is at least 20% lower than comparable jobs in the area. No pay raises for merit. Last pay raise was 3% which does not compensate for the real cost of living increase. Perks? a ridiculous one-time gas voucher of $25 to be used at the most expensive gas station in the area., and a "farmers'market" where staff received small bags with 3 potatoes and 1 onion. And we were supposed to be thrilled by that. There is no equity or consistency in work-from home opportunities. Some departments and some EAs have been working from home since the beginning of the pandemic, while others have been forced to be at the office. Absurd expectations to have administrative staff work on site on days when no executives are at the office, like the day after Thanksgiving and the week between Christmas and New Year's. Most executives work from home on Fridays while some EAs are supposed to be at the office "just in case". If you like to idea of being at a dead end job, being underpaid, and having to work on site while other colleagues enjoy working from home, suit yourself.

review_title: Ancillary staff extremely strained a lot of the time. But plenty of overtime if you want it.
job_title: Mental Health Associate in Princeton, NJ
pros: This is a good place to get experience. There is a lot of overtime if you want it.  Pay is okay.
cons: The supervisors play favorites, there is nepotism among the staff. The pay is okay for the type of position but too much inconsistency among the shifts. Shifts don't work together a lot of the time.  Micro-managing is a problem. No real room for advancement or raises.  Some staff is lazy and other staff has to pick up double the work and no reprimand to the lazy workers.

review_title: clicky and toxic management and work environment
pros: good location, benefits, great doctors, nurses, other employees and volunteers.
cons: People who have not worked any where else and have worked at this company only for many years act like they own the place and are totally disrespectful, bullish and discriminatory towards new hire minorities even though they are more qualified and experienced. Hostility and discrimination is rampant throughout the department starting from top level to bottom. Minorities are not promoted or given the opportunity to advance their career even though they may be more qualified and experienced. Management consists of all caucasians with majority of subordinates being minorities. If you are not part of the management click then you are ostracized, bullied and the work environment is turned punitive.

review_title: Excellent healthcare provided and overall good organization at which to work.
pros: Superiors and peers were intelligent, energetic, and willing to work as a team. I learned a great deal during my time working there. Benefits were very decent.
cons: Due to challenges of the healthcare industry as a whole, coupled with debt burden of new hospital construction, compensation was fair, but merit increases non-existent for several years and likely to continue. Additionally, there is very little flexibility with time management, i.e., no overtime permitted without prior management approval which was rarely, if ever, granted.

pros: Great benefits, Industry leader, Clean work environment. Up to date equipment and facilities. Flexible schedule and accommodating to individuals with severe chronic conditions.
cons: Under paid despite years of clinical experience and 170+ credit hours in my field. Certain departments are very cliquish and make the workplace toxic if you aren't part of the "in" crowd thus leading to horrible employee retention and frequent call outs. Lack of sharing information. Desire to grow is rarely followed through by management.

review_title: Good people to work with, high burnout rate due to stressful job and lack of appreciation by patients and administration
pros: Good people to work with,  high demand jobs and are ultimately working for a great cause.  Lots of different locations for moving around within the organization.
cons: High burnout rate, most people leave within 2-3 years, develop medical conditions from the stress, or stop caring as much about the patients and job.

review_title: Exciting job, perks, and opportunities; questionable ethics: not worth it
job_title: Mental Health Associate in Plainsboro, NJ
pros: MHAs are given a lot of freedom to use their individual strengths and be creative with groups, approaches. Great learning opportunity for the first time working in a hospital setting. Lots of trainings and opportunity to advance, move around, and find new interests. Pay and benefits are great (even for part-time).
cons: Part-time staff were not clued into major changes until arriving for a shift. Often times no communication between nursing and other disciplines, which caused a lot of frustration for patients. Lack of consistency with protocol and rules, which was difficult for this population especially, possibly even worsened behavior. Most significantly, huge staffing problem and very high turnover on my unit (eating disorders) because of the extra work spreading so few people so thin. Minimal training opportunities, unless I was able to commit to full-time hours at points, which defeats the purpose of having a part-time job. Charge nurses often asked me to stay for an additional shift in such a way that I was treated poorly if I set a boundary and said no. Lastly, I was disciplined for advocating on behalf of patients and told I was outside the scope of my duties while patient care was lacking. I ended up resigning for a neutral reason, thinking I'd left on good terms but had a nightmareish phone call with a rude HR representative when I was told I had been blacklisted for hiring throughout the entire company.

pros: The website is not allowing me to show 2012 as last year at employer. At that time the company was called Princeton House Behavioral Health. They offered consistent first rate trainings, and the company was very structured. Administrators were available, approachable, and there was a sense of pride to work for the Princeton Healthcare System.
cons: Again - as per 2012 when company was Princeton House Behavioral Health, Princeton Healthcare System - salaries were about $15,000 lower for therapists than what other companies were paying.

review_title: Don't be afraid to acquire new skills
pros: The IT Department provided plenty of opportunities to acquire new skill sets, but you get out of it what you put in.  Fellow employees have great attitudes generally and respect advice given.  Access to new technology for implementation is a core paradigm of company.
cons: Compensation is good, but as you acquire new skills, and put them to use, it is not often adjusted.  You could take on multiple roles if individuals leave with no increase in salary.

job_title: Registered Nurse/Case Manager in Princeton, NJ
pros: The salary is decent, flexible starting time
cons: micromanagement, they expect you to put time in at home, but not get paid for it.  Schedule really isn't that flexible, turnover has been high in the last year.  They say they want to hear your ideas, but they really don't.  Can never get consecutive days off near the holidays to go out of state to be with family.  Some management can be outright mean.

review_title: Great potential for an exceptional health organization
pros: Entire facility is state of the art, brand new, beautiful and innovative. The employees are all trained to smile and be friendly to patients as well as each other. An environment of healing is definitely promoted here.
cons: The administration is very political. There is a culture of severe disjointedness between the Administrative executives I.e the President, CEO, CFO, etc and the Physicians.

job_title: Mental Health Associate in Princeton, NJ
pros: I work at Princeton House Behavioral Health as a Mental Health Associate. decent work environment. decent pay. good coworkers. plenty of opportunity to work overtime. evening and overnight bosses are very nice.
cons: no opportunity for advancement. Nurses think they can boss you around. some people seem to get away with more than others. no performance based raises. Management makes it impossible to used paid time off.

review_title: Princeton House Behavioral Healthcare has a great team. However, their management is vindictive and evil.
pros: The admissions team was great to work with- everyone is positive and willing to lend a hand.
cons: The management is disorganized and sends their staff mixed messages. They also tended to play favorites, and held mistakes made months ago fresh in their minds, using it as ammunition to write awful progress reports. Also, HR is a joke and is not actually there to protect employees- they are very political with their choices.

review_title: Looks like a hotel, ran like a hotel

review_title: Stressful, like being in highschool all over.
job_title: Department Secretary in North Brunswick, NJ
pros: Ok  if you are trying to gain experience.
cons: Stressful office culture, alot of gossiping and he say she say. High turnover rate i was employed as a permanent employee for 2 months and in that time 4 people were fired and 6 people quit. Management never wants to help they just act like they are there for you. A lot of work for little pay.

pros: Therapists provide a community that is supportive and results in great transformation of clients.
cons: Low salary, changes within the company that do not take into account clients needs. Quick turn-over rate. Job demands are too high for the amount of time given. Huge gap between clinical staff and management. Management alienates staff and makes you feel unappreciated. Large organization that often feels cold and that it does not care about its employees. Just about making money, which is not why I got into this field.
